Content: [Music] Petty: So I can double-check that he put everything up.
The rest of them, I'm going to scan them all, yeah, so we can have them.
We have a, you know, our concept art directory.
You know, in theory if all the puzzles were done and the things were decided on, we could actually make a pretty functional game with really rough art early on
to sort of unblock the puzzle design or implementation.
And some of the systems work, which would be nice.
I'm not sure.
I'm a big fan of working that way, but I'm not sure if we'll be able to do it for this project or not.
We'll have to see how that works out.
[Music] Rice: Yep.
If you're always showing this board, won't they get spoilers from the board?
So just to bring us up to date, I need another location for the cloud nest.
Things that came up from the art jam.
Cloud nests.
Rice: You can tell that that's going to look awesome.
Schafer: The first thing Peter mentioned, too.
Rice: Yeah, I think he drew that the first day.
Schafer: And then the other one is the dead-eye pyramid.
Rice: Why is it dead-eye?
Schafer: Spoiler. Can't tell you.
Rice: I have to play the game to find out?
Schafer: These things all still work but maybe this becomes his story.
The monster lands move over here.
Maybe that moves over there.
Rice: What I still am not clear on is, and I don't know if you are, is switching back and forth between these stories
and how we're going to handle that.
Schafer: Yeah.
I'm putting that off.
Rice: Yeah. Start thinking about it.
So I'm just wondering then, like if I'm here, here and here and I jump back to this, then what's the world like?
Like why can't I do this and what happens that makes me so I can do this?
Schafer: I don't know. I don't know yet.
Schafer: I've been a little behind.
It's frustrating because I, when the team is waiting for you, that's always frustrating, so.
It's always been that way.
Like having an absolutely terrifying deadline is the only thing that, makes me get it done.
There's just so many other things going on with the company right now that, you know, The Cave is getting to this point where it needs, you know,
it has a dialogue deadline of its own.
You know, and do I help with that or do I work on this game?
Suck it!
[Monster Roar] Schafer: Peter McConnell's here today.
It's fun to see what he's going to add to it.
Schafer: So the game.
You see, we did some art already.
We had art jam with Peter Chan and Scott Campbell and Nathan came to town and hung out with Lee, and did some art.
And that's cool.
And that corkboard is kind of up-to-date.
I could add some as we talk, but we're doing a point and click graphic adventure.
I don't know if you heard that. McConnell: Very cool.
Schafer: So it doesn't have a high concept in terms of like a heavy metal fantasy world or the Day of the Dead.
It's really like a new world that we're making up based on Nathan Stapley's art.
You know, just having that cool look and having it be about themes that are different, maybe than other themes.
McConnell: Yeah. I've got questions.
Schafer: There'll be no questions during this meeting.
Schafer: Is Peter McConnell excited to be on the project?
You're asking me if he's excited?
I think so.
We always enjoyed working together.
You know, he's worked on everything I've done since Day of the Tentacle, Monkey II, Monkey II.
Offscreen Voice: He's like your Danny Elfman.
Schafer: He's what?
Offscreen Voice: He's like your Danny Elfman.
Schafer: He's like my Danny Elfman.
He can do Danny Elfman if you ask him to.
McConnell: I'm just thinking about instruments, you know.
I'm thinking about styles and I'm probably going to have to think quite a bit about it,
because it's, I mean, I have some things that are popping into my head.
I don't know if they're probably way jumping the gun at this point.
But what comes to mind about, about a world where things are being made for you and it's like a playroom a little bit, is a music box.
And you know, a little bit like Mr. Roger's Neighborhood, which…
Schafer: It also has that repetitive quality to it.
Because the game is going to start in this like, his routine is the same every day, even though it's drastically different.
It's really like he wakes up, the robots dress him.
You know, the arms just come out of nowhere and make him dinner, food.
And then when he busts out and he's doing actual 90's, 80's creepy space adventure.
Or 2001 like.
McConnell: Yeah. Schafer: Yeah.
McConnell: Then 2001 would be, 2001 will be hard to do, you know, without a great big orchestra.
And I don't think we have that.
But I don't think, you know.
Schafer: And now it's like a little more like now we're running our own actual budget.
Schafer: It's like we have a certain amount of money in the budget for Peter, which means a certain amount of time.
And we have to like wait until we're ready for him to be really effective in working.
So we've got to be at a point where we can just tell him, here's a list of characters that need themes.
Here's a list of areas, 'cause he's got to spread out his time so he doesn't just score the first two acts and then run out of time.
So he's got to like spread it out, look at the whole game, think about the game play.
Then think about how much of that money he should save to pay for things like live musicians.
Studio time.
McConnell: Yeah, I think there is going to have to be a signature piece, for sure.
And that is, or you know, or two halves of the signature piece because you got these two worlds.
Min: Yeah, yeah, that, too.
Rice: It'll be interesting to see how we can handle that.
You know, like if there're themes that persist in both their worlds or you know, funny little things to do to connect their two.
Min: I think that Pete's going to be able to knock that out pretty easily.
I think it's more the initial, but then it's the same thing with Tim, you know, I mean you go crazy for two days
and then on the third day you just kind of come up with something.
You know, that's how creative magic happens.
I mean, and I think it's almost like you have to be patient with yourself and not, not panic.
McConnell: You know, that backer money don't last forever.
Rice: That's the truth.
Music Lumberjack: That's not a word, is it?
Tree: No. We're done here.
Kipnis: Yes! Schafer: Awesome. Done. Rice: Yeah.
For the last four months we've spent in preproduction mode and it's been kind of exploratory phase of trying to figure out what the game is
and both in terms of design, but also in how we're going to actually make that happen.
But yeah, everyone's kind of had their own separate little tasks and those are all starting to converge now to where
we're ready to start actually building a puzzle in the engine.
Crook: Actual production work is awesome.
Like we're going to go, this could get shipped.
Like this work.
Schafer: We'll see how it turns out.
Crook: Yeah, we'll see.
Rice: Ray Crook, Double Fine animator.
Yeah, Ray started on the project and he's been someone who's been at the company since like essentially the beginning.
Crook: I was excited to work with Tim again, because Brutal Legend was the last game that,
you know, we'd worked closely together on.
And so I was most excited just to work with him.
But you know, I knew there would be cameras.
Crook: So I'm actually excited to be starting on that.
Crook: You know, the beginning of preproduction is really exciting and then it seems like eventually it gets kind of like,
you're just kind of churning.
You know, I guess just, let's just get this show on the road, you know, is sort of the way that it feels.
And that's where we are.
Schafer: Awesome. Bye.
Crook: Tim has picked a puzzle, which we're calling First Playable.
Petty: So these are some of the stuff Peter gave me on Friday, right?
And so I think this is the stuff we talked about when he was here, which is the idea of them having this little sacrificial island, which is awesome.
Cakes, in a U. But I was still worried about like if you put this into game camera mode, game layout mode,
that'd be kind of blocked up.
And I did this real rough thing.
I just got Peter's revision, right.
And so this was the idea like from a game camera you would be, you would kind of start here.
So we could start with a pan and we kind of move up and we kind of…
Rice: But yeah, it's the scene where the main character, I mean main female character is being offered up for sacrifice to a monster.
Schafer: Could it show up just behind the princess?
You just see something like feet?
Like what the fuck is it!? Petty: Yeah.
Schafer: You can't see it all, then it comes between, like oh my God!
And it's gone.
You just never see it up close until it gets, comes in here and like eats that one.
Rice: Yeah, it's going to be a lot of work, for sure, because it's just a lot of animation and cut scenes.
So it's going to be a tough one.
Stapley: So you're saying for the end of this sprint we're really going to try to get the, get the sacrifice feast all set up?
'Cause that's the thing, like if every puzzle's going to have like say five or so new characters, that's like, kind of a lot of time.
Petty: Well, and that's exactly why we want to take this to finals, because it's just conjecture
until we kind of get an area to really know exactly how long.
I made estimates based on our progress.
Petty: Like there's always this period that when you start any game where you're trying to, you're trying to build it,
you're trying to build something both at like artistically you're like yeah, it's the right mood, that's the right game play, that's the right look.
But you're also trying to build something to get an idea of how long it takes you to build the rest of the game.
And part of that is you need, you need enough information about the rest of the game,
like you know, there's always this theoretical ideal that you never get.
Like the whole game is written, every puzzle's designed, you know, all the art direction's completely done.
I've never in my whatever years I've worked in the game industry, ever seen that happen.
Some projects are closer to that than others.
So there's a lot of uncertainty at that point.
Stapley: Yeah, sounds good and scary.
Schafer: Bagel, why you so scared?
Stapley: I think because I haven't seen anything like in the game yet, you know.
Like it's still the lumberjack dude.
I'd just love to see how easy it's going to be reshape things and put things in and take things out and change things and add things.
Petty: What you really have to do, I think, is lay the best foundation you can.
Be mindful of what you're making and then just be clever as you're making the game.
Look for opportunities to save time or to reuse things or to go in new directions that are just more efficient
or take some of the lessons you've learned from the earlier areas and adapt your later areas to it.
So, that's, and that's, that's what I try and do and I think most people on the team try to do it in any game.
[Music] Offscreen Voice: She wants to be skinny, right?
And look skinny.
So maybe it's something that helps her look slimmer sometime?
Schafer: Corset. Offscreen Voice: Yeah.
Schafer: But you put corset on the buzzard.
Oh, wait. That could be awesome.
Offscreen Voice: That could be totally awesome.
Schafer: So strange. A corset buzzard with a drumstick in his arm.
This is where I start getting interested.
Schafer: Like I haven't seen like the maiden feast thing all wired up yet, but that is in the game, I hear.
Have you seen that?
I've been out of it in meetings.
Things are happening so fast.
Petty: You know what did so far in it, is you know, we had this sort of layout drawing that we did.
And we took those layout drawings and cut them up.
And you can sort of see things exist in the tool here in parallax.
We don't have the game camera authored or anything, like you know, you could rough in the game play right now if you wanted to.
This isn't the, a real monster design.
That's not a real bird design.
Those aren't real character designs, but they are, you know, they have the underlying script components to them.
And so, you know, once those, you can sort of see here this is just, if we run the game at this scene at the moment
we don't actually have a main character.
So you know, one could hookup dialogue and have proxy object dragging and all that sort of stuff.
So that's the biggest thing I want to do with it, was put enough of it together that Bagel could do some painting and learn from the painting.
And if the programmers want to script that one first they can.
Franzke: Stuff should go time-wise like, well, at least roughly, right, you need those animations
Kipnis: Think of the sound guys, that's what they use as well.
Petty: Well, this happened but their workflow, all they do, is they take…
Kipnis: Oh! [Power out] Schafer: Well, it is lunchtime.
Offscreen Voice: It could have been worse.
Offscreen Voice: Do you see yourself having a huge workload on this?
Crook: Yes. Yeah, we started going through it and I figure, I mean it's a Tim Schafer game.
He likes characters, he likes dialogue.
And there'll be cut scenes.
Crook: I don't know.
I'm not sure what Tim wants as far as fidelity on cut scenes.
Like I don't know.
Petty: The question is how Full Throttle are we?
Crook: Right. Right.
For an animator this is horrible. But, Franzke: I mean, like what if you could just do all that stuff in Maya
Crook: We'll see how much of it we can auto-gen as far as like lip-sync and that sort of thing.
I just, I just hope, you know, sometimes you do something, you think, oh, we'll just automate it.
And then you do it and like ah, it's not going to work.
You know, we need to just have, you know, artists go in and do this.
Crook: So this was sort of a test animation that I did yesterday.
And so she's stuck in this cake.
And then this just shows you her turning, just to see what kind of, if we can get a quick turn out of her.
And so we already have the composition decided on so we know what the position of each of these characters will be in.
So when Bagel did the initial designs, which is here, he took that into consideration.
And so we know that she will never have to turn any more than what she does right there.
Rice: Just because that's kind of a whole new process, the 2D animation is something we haven't done here at Double Fine.
And we're doing it in a way that is similar to how we animate in 3D so that helps.
But that could easily be something that's a lot more work than we're expecting.
Petty: Yeah, I'm not sure how we're going to handle the tentacles because when we talked about maybe doing them purely as flip book animation,
because we are, we don't have, we can't have enough joints in this engine to do, to like animate them all freely.
Schafer: Is there a special close-up monster different than the...?
Petty: We don't do any special close-up.
We do one version for everything unless we have to do it, because it's just a lot more work.
Schafer: Maybe not to joint everything that you don't want to joint.
Or is it the painting of the details or is the mouth shapes and all that stuff?
Petty: All the above.
Rice: We're still working on like our first playable puzzle from the actual game.
We kind of bit off a big one.
So that's happening now.
Crook: So you know, when I was creating lists and I've been working with Lee on schedule
and it's, it's, it's going to get hairy, I think.
Petty: And then his overall layout of that area, I think this shows, this shows where it is relative to the village.
Schafer: Things look great.
Schafer: So we'll meet with Peter.
Chan: This is kind of the square, but I, you know, it could be a lot bigger, but I wanted to just show what it might look like down the street.
Schafer: I guess I'd like, I haven't seen any, I mean, I like the...
Schafer: Yeah, some things are bugging me about those mushroom houses.
For one, I hate mushrooms.
But two, it's like, oh, mushroom houses.
What is that making me think of?
And I thought Smurfs.
Schafer: You know, my only worry about the mushroom town is if it invokes Smurfdom, you know, because there is that kind of Smurf shape with mushrooms a little bit.
So when I see the big castle's one big mushroom, you know, there's parts, there's shapes of mushrooms that don't evoke that and there's shapes that do.
Petty: Like this doesn't really, right? Chan: OK.
Schafer: No, that looks more like a…
Chan: Greg? When is my last day?
Petty: August tenth. August tenth.
Chan: Wow. OK.
So then we are, it's... Rice: Getting there.
Chan: We're running out of time.
Schafer: Get drawing right now.
Chan: We've only just scratched the surface really, by that. We're still...
Schafer: We'll get more money later and have you back.
Rice: You know, we got a lot of money but that money goes a lot of places and it's expensive to run a studio like Double Fine in San Francisco.
So there's only so long we can have this many people on the project without running out of money.
We've got to make sure that we make something great in that amount of time.
Schafer: OK.
Chan: Anything else? Schafer: Not me.
Petty: No, no. I'll call you soon.
Chan: OK, cool. I'm going to hang up.
You guys have a great rest of the day.
Schafer: Thanks, you too Peter. Bye.
Chan: OK, thank you, bye-bye.
Schafer: So like I really do like all this stuff, and this stuff.
And that all works, too.
Like I was, I hope I didn't hurt his feelings by saying Smurfs.
Sometimes you never know...Smurfs..
Petty: It's really hard not to offend artists all the time.
Schafer: But that's my only worry about some of this stuff.
Because I, I mean, I like it but he did go, like the very first thing that he ever talked about
was this Japanese/Scandinavian combination mushroom thing.
And so it's really hard to say like I like it, but I had seen anything else, except I did also like
some of Bagel's crazy geometric weird thing that he was doing, too.
That was kind of a unique look for the castle.
Yeah, I mean I know Bagel's got a lot of backgrounds to do but I would like to see if he could come up with any ideas about the buzzard.
Petty: So is Bagel, yeah, I mean, so what we have to do, like with, I guess we can talk about this in the reviews or review meeting,
but Bagel right now, just, just to paint what we already designed for just the sacrifice puzzle will take him this entire sprint.
He doesn't, he really doesn't have time for, for any concept art at all.
He has time to interpret it like when he gets to like paint it and that's sort of built into the time.
And if, we can certainly do any of that but it comes at the cost of we either need to come up with another solution for painting that-
Schafer: The problem with that is that doesn't really solve the problem of like having a game be in Bagel's style.
'Cause if he isn't doing the concept part of it, then it's not really, Petty: well I dissagree... Schafer: it's his rendering style but it's not his like...
Petty: But that's what his painting is.
You're not using the content from his painting.
You're not using the "Bob's Big Boy" Schafer: When I talked about like wanting to capture
some of the crazy stuff from his fine art show, there was a little guy on the table or the woman with the mouth in her hair.
Like those are more ideas than about a rendering style.
So like I wanted to capture some of Bagel's, some more surreal ideas in the game concept, too.
Not just, not just his rendering style, for sure.
Petty: Well then we need to come up with another plan, because right now it's not possible.
Schafer: But, 'cause I'm torn.
Because I also want Bagel to do concepts, like come up with crazy ideas.
That's one of the things I like about his art, is that he has these, you know, kind of crazy surreal ideas in his painting.
Not just the rendering style of it.
Rice: But yeah, I mean it was a hard choice, you know, when Tim decided that he wanted the game to reflect Bagel's style.
Ultimately that means that he's going to have to paint a lot of the game, if not all of the game.
And it's going to be what makes the game have kind of a cohesive feel and look.
Petty: I don't see how it's going to work.
So we could either do something like, you know, someone else could render the characters
to give him time to do concept design or someone, I don't know.
Something like that, some hybrid sort of rendering style solution that can work in a very similar style.
That's the only, you know, we'll have to figure something like that out.
Because there just isn't time for one person to do all that.
Schafer: I love this meeting wherein we talk about can't be done.
Because those are always like, those are kind of a drag, 'cause you're like trying, you're trying to invent stuff.
You know, you're having this problem with nothing to something, like OK, I got an idea.
And someone says that'll take three years; you can't do it.
And you're like oh.
Do you know how hard that was to have that idea?
Schafer: OK, I have to go do something.
Petty: OK. So...
Schafer: As much as I would like to talk about how we can't make this awesome game in time.
Petty: I thought I was coming up with ways that we could.
Schafer: I know. I'm going to check out that inventory stuff.
Rice: Bye.
Schafer: Hey, Anna. Kipnis: Yeah?
Can I see all that cool inventory stuff I missed?
Petty: We're just going to wind up shipping a game about a red bot and a fucking lumberjack.
Sorry, Tim.
We decided to ship these instead.
Crook: Ran out of time.
Franzke: We ran out of time. We did create all kind of tech for it...
Thank God it's up to you to make a game.
Here's a tool set, go do whatever you want.
Rice: Yeah, I think there's always a point in a project where everything kind of gets real and you see the amount of work
that you have in front of you.
There was a bit of an eye-opener just through the docs and the processes as far as how much work is left.
And how much we can, we can do.
And the amount of time we have left.
Rice: It was an eye-opener that we needed to get to the moment where we're like OK, we need to start building this game.
And we're getting to the point where yeah, where now the real work is beginning.
Schafer: Who was it, it was like Miyamoto.
He said that famous quote about like it only hurts until it's done, but if it sucks, it sucks forever, you know.
Schafer: So like OK, we'll suffer now, we'll put the extra work in to make this great,
because no one's going to remember, you know, no one ever says about a game like, oh you know, that game had a really reasonable production cycle.
That was, I really enjoyed that game.
It was really moderately scheduled.
Rice: This was our fourth milestone of 13.
So we need to start kind of pushing forward, getting some content together if we're going to stay on track.
Schafer: I mean, off of what I'm pushing for is like we should just think about this problem longer,
because we're going to have a creative solution that's going to allow us to have the great thing that I want,
but have it not take 20 years to put together.
It'll take, we'll think of the cheap.
You know, Lee and those guys are really smart and they could probably think of a clever way to, you know,
cut the work in half and get it done.
Schafer: But it's hard to commit to that in advance.
Like OK, I'll have a clever idea and it'll cut this work in half, 'cause you know, those things you don't know they're going to come.
But they always come.
[Music] Offscreen Voice: Bye, guys. See you tomorrow.
[Music] Rice: Potentially getting some art interns from the Institute.
That could do, you know, like the menial tasks nobody wants to do.
Franzke: Well not even menial, like, I mean all of my plans...
